This is kind of a tricky question. The simple way of answering would be no, a belief in and of itself can't be immoral, unless you act on it in a way that hurts or disadvantages others who have not harmed you in any way. But that's a bit too simplistic. Not everything we do is carefully monitored and guided by our most noble and compassionate tendencies, and we have many unexamined biases that may play a role in our decisions and actions. We also have very imperfect knowledge of all the downstream consequences of the actions we take based on our beliefs. So even at our most conscious and noble, we may engage in immoral behavior stemming from our unexamined biases, and situations in which we neglect to consciously "check in" with our own ethics before deciding or acting.

This is a good question but fraught with ambiguity and subjectiveness. What one believes is immoral depends on one’s early nurturing and environmental influences. One’s code of morality and immorality is subjective, just as is religion itself—from which most folks form their subjective opinions about immorality. For example, a great many people in the western nations believe that a woman breastfeeding her baby in public is immoral because her breast is showing. many do not—it’s a natural thing. That is a subjective opinion. Others, especially in Islam, believe that a woman who does not have her entire body including ankles, neck and arms covered, is being immoral. Still others, such as myself, believe that forcing women to cover themselves is immoral. Most societies believe public nakedness is immoral. Other societies do not. Even in very religious nations, such as in the U.S., quasi-public nudity (quasi meaning a community of nude people is allowed so long as it is separated from the general public) is allowed because the U.S. has a secular Constitution that recognizes every individual’s beliefs in matters of morality and religion are as valid as the next person’s. It is the right to have a free conscience.

A belief can be immoral, but that does not mean that it is necessary legal, nore ethical. It can be all three: immoral, legal and ethical, or any combination of these three. It is therefore a question that has many answers that are as subjective as philosophy can be. It is also lends itself for a great discussion with friends over dinner.

A belief is a manifestation of freedom of expression. A belief is also a thought process and is therefore an inherently human reaction to the world around us. Until and unless such a belief is translated into action to the detriment of society, it remains benign. But can a belief be immoral? Yes!

No. Only actions can be immoral. You can hold true or false beliefs, even nonsensical beliefs, but not moral or immoral ones. You could hold a belief, that if you acted on it the action would be immoral. Morality only addresses harms (and to a lesser extent benefits) to moral agents. Thoughts that no one ever knows about other than the thinker of course, cannot harm anyone else and so are not within the realm of morality.
